article:
'Colony-stimulating factors' (CSFs) are secreted glycoproteins that bind to
receptor proteins on the surfaces of hemopoietic stem cells, thereby activating
intracellular signaling pathways that can cause the cells to proliferate and
differentiate into a specific kind of blood cell (usually white blood cells. For
red blood cell formation, see erythropoietin).

They may be synthesized and administered exogenously. However, such molecules
can at a latter stage be detected, since they differ slightly from the
endogenous ones in, e.g., features of posttranslational modification.
